header.title: The Grand Grimoire With The Great Clavicle of Solomon
header.category: Western Esotericism, Grimoire Tradition, Ceremonial Magic

central_thesis: The Grand Grimoire outlines a powerful system, purportedly derived from King Solomon's wisdom, for compelling infernal spirits, primarily Lucifuge Rofocale, into pacts to acquire hidden treasures, gain supernatural abilities, and achieve various worldly desires through rigorous preparatory rituals, the use of consecrated tools, and potent invocations, emphasizing strict adherence to procedure and the potential for eternal damnation if terms are not met.

structure_content.summary: Introduces the book as 'The Great Work,' a rare and profound compilation from King Solomon's search for hidden secrets. It asserts Solomon's ability to command spirits through his clavicle, powerful words, and knowledge of divine secrets, including astral influences and the creation of a 'fulminating rod' capable of controlling natural phenomena and striking down rebel angels.

Warns practitioners of the immense power and danger of this science, stressing the absolute necessity of steadfastness, constancy, prudence, and exact adherence to instructions to avoid 'disadvantage, confusion and total loss.' It details initial preparations, including a quarter-month of abstinence, specific daily prayers to ADONAY, acquiring and carrying a protective Bloodstone (Ematille), and the ritualistic sacrifice of a virgin kid (adorned with vervain, cut with a steel blade) with specific invocations to ADONAY, ELOHIM, ARIEL, and JEHOVA. The kid's skin is retained for the magic circle, and its ashes are cast to the rising sun.

Describes the creation and consecration of the 'fulminating rod' (also referred to as the blasting rod or wand). This involves selecting a specific wild hazel branch (fruitless, forked, 19.5 inches long) and cutting it at sunrise with the blade used for sacrifice, accompanied by a powerful invocation to ADONAY, ELOHIM, ARIEL, JEHOVA, invoking the strength of biblical figures. The rod's ends are capped with steel blades from the sacrificial knife and magnetized with a lodestone. The chapter concludes by listing all necessary ritual items for the 'Great Work': the consecrated rod, kid skin, bloodstone, vervain garlands, two candleholders, two pounds of blessed virgin wax, a lodestone, smooth flintstones, spirit of water, incense, camfora, and four nails from a child's coffin.

Provides precise instructions for constructing the 'great cabalistic circle' at a solitary location. The kid's skin is nailed down with the four coffin nails. A triangle is drawn inside the circle, and four protective letters are marked outside using the Bloodstone, along with the sacred name '† JHS †' for defense. The Karcist (operator) and associates enter the triangle, lighting two candles (adorned with vervain) and a continuous flame in a new vase containing willow wood ash, spirit of water, incense, and camfora. An offering prayer to ADONAY, ELOHIM, ARIEL, and JEHOVA is made. Strict warnings are given against wearing impure metal and allowing anyone other than the Karcist to speak during the ritual, with specific instructions for using gold or silver coins as payment to spirits.

Presents a sequence of escalating invocations to Emperor Lucifer, commanding him to appear or send his messenger Astaroth, using divine names (ADONAY, ELOHIM, ARIEL, JEHOVA, TAGLA, MATHON) and threatening eternal torment with the blasting rod if he fails to comply immediately. A 'Warning' section advises striking the rod into the fire and repeating the third invocation if the spirit does not appear, indicating that horrible cries will precede its manifestation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Grand Invocation of the Great Kabbala
structure_content.summary: Offers an ultimate invocation for compelling spirits, to be used if previous invocations fail. This involves striking the rod into the fire again and reciting a lengthy, powerful string of divine, angelic, and magical names (e.g., AGLA, TAGLA, MATHON, OARIOS, ALMOAZIN, ARIOS, MEMBROT, VARIOS, PITHONA, MAJODS, SULPHAE, GABOTS, SALAMANDRAE, TABOTS, GINGUA, JANNA, ETITNAMUS, ZARIATNATMIX), combined with cross symbols, to force immediate appearance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Apparition of the Spirit, Query & Response, Pact
structure_content.summary: Details the spirit's (Lucifuge Rofocale's) initial appearance and dialogue. The Karcist commands Lucifuge to appear twice daily and reveal the nearest treasure, promising a monthly gold/silver coin. Lucifuge initially demands the Karcist's body and soul for fifty years. Solomon's 'Warning' reiterates threats with the blasting rod. Lucifuge then agrees to a pact: he will reveal treasure and appear at specific times, approving the Grimoire, and providing his signature, provided the Karcist keeps the secret, is charitable, and offers a monthly coin. Failure to comply means forfeiture of the Karcist's soul in 20 years. The pact is sealed with a blood signature on virgin parchment.

structure_content.chapter_title: Consequences of the Pact and Dismissal
structure_content.summary: Describes the spirit, Lucifuge Rofocale, leading the Karcist to the treasure, potentially encountering a gnome-dog (to be driven away with the rod). The Karcist must throw a written conjuration over the treasure, throw a bitten coin, and retrieve the treasure by walking backward, explicitly warned against looking back or fearing noises. After securing the treasure, a final dismissal prayer to Lucifer is given, reaffirming satisfaction with the spirit's service and threatening continued torment with the blasting rod if the pact is broken. The section concludes with prayers of thanksgiving to God and self-protection from evil spirits, along with lengthy Latin invocations.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Second Book: Sanctum Regnum (Pacts without Rod/Circle)
structure_content.summary: Introduces alternative methods for making pacts without the complex blasting rod or circle, for those lacking the capacity for the First Book's rigorous preparations. It focuses on gaining treasures, earthly pleasures, uncovering secrets, achieving invisibility, weather control, necromancy, and other 'surprising things.' It lists the hierarchy of infernal spirits: Lucifer (Emperor), Belzebuth (Prince), Astaroth (Grand Duke), and their superior ministers (Lucifuge Rofocale, Satanachia, Agliarept, Fleurèty, Sargatanas, Nebiros), each with specific powers and control over 18 subordinate spirits. The invocation process for Lucifuge Rofocale is similar but culminates in a 20-year soul-forfeit pact, signed in blood on parchment.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Magick Secret; or The Art of Speaking with the Dead
structure_content.summary: Details a ritual for necromancy, performed at midnight mass on Christmas Eve. The practitioner pronounces specific words when the Host is lifted, then proceeds to a cemetery, offering prayers to 'Infernal powers' at the first tomb. Further steps involve collecting earth, kneeling facing East, and using bones of a dead man (placed in a Saint Andrew's cross) to summon a specter to answer questions after walking 5,900 steps westward.

structure_content.chapter_title: Secrets of the Magick Art (Various Spells)
structure_content.summary: Presents a collection of diverse spells and recipes: The 'Composition of Death, or Philosopher's Stone' (an alchemical method to produce gold); instructions for making and activating a divining rod; enchanting firearms; winning lotteries; speaking with spirits on St. John the Baptist's Eve; becoming insensible to torture; compelling someone to dance naked; making oneself invisible (involving a black cat and bones); gaining favor with judges; imperviousness to weapons; creating a 'garter of twenty miles per hour' (from a wolf's skin); a plaster for fast travel; a special ink for writing pacts; 'Solomon's Mirror' (a 48-day scrying ritual involving a steel plate, dove's blood, and invocations to Anael); the 'Secret of the Black Hen' (a pact ritual for wealth); love spells; and various other practical enchantments and recipes (e.g., preventing conception, determining fertility, mending porcelain).

structure_content.chapter_title: Table of Auspicious and Inauspicious Days
structure_content.summary: Provides a calendar of days, month by month, deemed favorable ('Auspicious Days') and unfavorable ('Inauspicious Days') for magical operations, asserting its dictation by an angel to Abraham.

key_concepts.term: Grand Grimoire / Great Clavicle of Solomon
key_concepts.definition: The foundational text describing a system of ceremonial magic attributed to King Solomon, primarily focused on compelling infernal spirits to grant desires, especially wealth.
The primary magical weapon, a consecrated forked hazel branch, imbued with divine power through specific invocations, used to command, threaten, and compel spirits.

A protective ritual space constructed with the skin of a sacrificed kid, marked with a bloodstone-drawn triangle, specific letters, and the name '† JHS †', serving as a sanctuary for the Karcist and associates during conjuration.

Formal agreements made between the Karcist and infernal spirits (notably Lucifuge Rofocale) for mutual benefit, often involving the exchange of worldly goods or powers for the Karcist's soul (after a set period), monthly offerings, and secrecy. These pacts are sealed with blood signatures on virgin parchment.
The chief operator or magician who performs the rituals and invokes the spirits.

key_concepts.term: ADONAY, ELOHIM, ARIEL, JEHOVA, TAGLA, MATHON
key_concepts.definition: Key divine names used in invocations to assert authority over spirits and provide protection to the Karcist. These names are seen as sources of immense power within the Solomonic tradition.
The Emperor of the rebel spirits, ultimately responsible for the hierarchy of infernal entities. Direct invocations are made to him to compel his subordinates.
The Prime Minister of the infernal realm, directly commanding worldly riches and treasures, and the principal spirit summoned for pacts involving material gain in the Grand Grimoire.
A protective gem carried by the Karcist to ward off fear and worry, and also used as a tool to delineate the magical circle and triangle.
A scrying device, typically a polished steel plate, consecrated over 48 days with specific rituals and invocations to the angel Anael, enabling the Karcist to perceive hidden knowledge and desires.
A distinct, powerful, and secretive ritual for making pacts and acquiring wealth, involving the sacrifice of a specific black hen at a crossroads at midnight, and uttering potent invocations.

practical_system.description: The Grand Grimoire presents a detailed operative system of ceremonial magic, divided into two books. The first book describes a complex Solomonic method requiring extensive purification, the consecration of specialized tools (like the blasting rod), and the construction of a protective cabalistic circle to compel powerful infernal spirits, such as Lucifuge Rofocale, into physical manifestation and service. The second book offers less demanding methods for spirit pacts, focusing on direct invocation to achieve various ends without the full array of complex tools. The core of the system is the negotiation and sealing of a pact with a spirit for material gain or supernatural powers, often involving a soul-forfeiture clause, counterbalanced by divine invocations for protection and authority. The text also includes various auxiliary 'magick secrets' for diverse practical applications beyond direct spirit conjuration.
tools: Wild hazel tree branch (forked, 19.5 inches) for the blasting rod
Gold or silver coin (for spirit payment)
Sponge, pure milk, fine oil (for preventing conception)
Deer fat, hot water (for fertility test)
Pigeon heart, frog head (for secrets spell)
Gold studded plate, mortuary sheet, quince tree branch (for supernatural sight)
Lamp wick, sea foam, sulfur, litharge (for darkening rooms)
Wine spirits, Gum Arabic (for crystal glue)
Egg whites, quicklime, milk (for porcelain glue)
Newborn foal's forehead flesh, gold ring with diamond, green fabric, scribe/engraver, hairs (from self and target), apple, green myrtle twig, bay/myrtle leaves (for love spells)
Fern (for speaking with spirits of St. John)
Human fat, stag oil, bay-tree oil, natural mummy, spirit of wine, vervain leaves, wolf skin (for travel plaster)
River water, fern sprigs, vine twigs, gall nuts, Roman Vitriol/Green Copperas, Rock Alum, Gum Arabic (for special ink)
Shiny steel plate, white dove's blood, new white cloth, laurel wood ashes, perfume, saffron (for Solomon's Mirror)
rituals: Quarter-month purification: abstinence from sex, specific meal times, and daily prayers to ADONAY.
Sacrifice of a virgin kid on the third day, adorned with vervain, with specific invocations to ADONAY, ELOHIM, ARIEL, and JEHOVA. The skin is preserved, ashes scattered to the sun.

Consecration of the 'fulminating rod': a specific hazel branch cut at sunrise with the sacrificial blade, invoking biblical strengths and divine names. Capped with steel, magnetized with a lodestone, and consecrated with a prayer.
Construction of the 'great cabalistic circle': using the kid skin, four nails from a child's coffin, Bloodstone to draw a triangle and protective letters, and inscribing '† JHS †'.

Circle ritual: Karcist and associates enter the circle, light candles (with vervain), and maintain a continuous flame in a vase with willow ash, spirit of water, incense, and camfora. An offering prayer is made.

Escalating invocations: a sequence of prayers and commands to ADONAY, ELOHIM, ARIEL, JEHOVA, Emperor Lucifer, and Lucifuge Rofocale, including threats with the blasting rod if the spirit fails to appear.
Grand Invocation of the Great Kabbala: a powerful last resort invocation with numerous divine names and symbols, accompanied by striking the blasting rod into fire.

Pact negotiation and sealing: direct dialogue with Lucifuge Rofocale, agreeing to terms (e.g., treasure for 20 years of soul service, monthly coin offering), and signing a blood pact on virgin parchment.

Treasure retrieval: following the spirit to the treasure, driving away a gnome-dog with the rod, throwing a written conjuration over the treasure, throwing a bitten coin, and withdrawing backward without looking back.
Dismissal of the spirit: specific words of dismissal to Lucifer, reinforcing the pact and threatening retribution if violated.
Thanksgiving prayers: to God for success and for protection from evil spirits (including Latin prayers).

The Black Hen ritual: selecting a specific hen, sacrificing it at 11 PM, taking it to a crossroads at midnight, forming a circle with a Cyprus branch, cutting the hen while invoking 'ELOHIM, ESSAIM,' and performing a prayer for a pact and wealth.

Solomon's Mirror creation: a 48-day ritual involving purification, inscribing divine names (JEHOVA, ELOHIM, MITRATHON, ADONAY) with dove's blood on a steel plate, and invocations to the angel Anael for scrying.
Art of Speaking with the Dead: a Christmas midnight mass ritual, followed by a cemetery visit, offerings to infernal powers, collecting earth, and using bones to summon specters.

Minor spells: rituals for invisibility (black cat bones), love (gold ring, hairs, apple), protection (writing on arm), luck (frog parts), influencing judges, enchanting firearms, fast travel (wolf skin garters, magical plaster), and preparing special ink for pacts.

relevant_quotes.text: This Book is so rare and sought after in our country it has been called, by our Rabbis, the true Great Work.

Arm yourselves then with intrepidation, prudence and virtuosity in order to succeed at this great and immense task, at which I have spent 67 years working day and night. To succeed at this great goal it is necessary to do exactly that which I will hereby indicate. ----Solomon
I command you, Emperor Lucifer, by the great living God, his dear son and the Holy Ghost and by the power of the great ADONAY, ELOHIM, ARIEL AND JEHOVA, to appear now or send me your ASTAROTH.
I cannot grant your request except on the condition that you give yourself to me for the next 20 years so that I can use your body and soul as I see fit. --------Lucifuge Rofocale
I promise to repay the great Lucifuge in 20 years for all of the treasures that he will give me. On my honor I sign this in good faith. --------Signature in blood
Lucifuge commands the first three who are called Bael, Agares and Marbas. Satanachia over Pruslas, Aamon and Barbatos.

critical_analysis.relevance: The Grand Grimoire holds significant relevance within Western Esotericism and the grimoire tradition as one of the most explicit and infamous texts detailing infernal pacts for material gain. Unlike many Solomonic works that focus on benevolent control, this grimoire directly outlines how to compel powerful demons, particularly Lucifuge Rofocale, to reveal treasures or grant other desires, often in exchange for the practitioner's soul over a specified period. It provides a stark counterpoint to 'white magic' grimoires, embodying the archetype of 'black magic' through its direct engagement with Luciferian figures and emphasis on binding rather than benevolent conjuration. Historically, it contributed to the popular understanding and fear of demon-pacting. Its blend of traditional Christian divine names for authority and elaborate demonology, combined with a highly practical and prescriptive approach to ritual, offers valuable insight into the development of operative magic and its moral complexities.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of experienced ceremonial magicians, occult practitioners, and serious scholars of Western Esotericism and demonology. It is specifically aimed at individuals seeking direct interaction with infernal spirits for the acquisition of power, wealth, or specific supernatural abilities, who are willing to undertake rigorous and potentially perilous rituals, including the explicit or implicit pledging of their soul. The text assumes a high degree of courage, resolve, and a readiness to engage with controversial and morally ambiguous magical practices.
